title: heroic mum gives birth big
story: Heroic mum gives birth to big baby weighing  pounds without any pain reliefWhen Victoria Cook welcomed son Jack, he was born as one of the biggest children of his age in the country - but she said the experience was so positive she even FaceTimed her mum during labourVictoria Cook wanted to do things dferently - and said no to pain relief Image: Mercury Press  Media Ltd.BySam Elliott-GibbsReporterBeth Ure:,  Mar |commentsA resilient mum gave birth to a -pound baby weighing the same as a sack of potatoes after a gruelling seven-hour labour - without any pain relief. Victoria Cook, , welcomed her son Jack five months ago with him weighing a whopping lbs oz. Despite only having gas and air to get her through, Victoria says she felt very little pain - and really enjoyed the experience.She was in labour for hours in the birthing centre near her home in London last September but it appears she loved every moment of it. The nurses told her how peaceful the process was - despite little Jack being one of the biggest babies of his age in the country when he was born.  Victoria said: I know it sounds ridiculous but it almost didnapost hurt, it was quite a quick delivery. His shoulder got a bit stuck on the way out, which was painful, but on the whole, it was a really positive experience.We opted for a birthing centre instead of a labour ward in the hospital and we were lucky enough to have another water birth. It sounds a bit hippie, but we had nature sounds playing in the background during labour as well, so that was really nice.  Every time we had a nurse come in or anything they would say aposwow itaposs so peaceful in hereapos! Victoria says she would highly recommend a birthing centre to any soon-to-be-mums. She said: Itaposs midwe run, so itaposs less medical than going to a hospital and much more natural. The water birth was so great as well, itaposs such a relief during labour to get into the warm water, it takes the strain off your back as well. We had a lovely corner room as well, so there was lots of sunlight flooding in. Giving birth can be really daunting, and I think we donapost talk about a lot of the details of it enough.  So many people have horror stories, and a traumatic birth experience, so I want people to know itaposs possible to give birth to a lb baby and walk away from it! Victoriaaposs experience was so positive, she even ended up face-timing her mum during labour. She said: I donapost really know what I was thinking, looking back, but at the time it seemed like a great idea. I was doing little video tours of the room and I spoke to my brotheraposs we, Liana, because she was only ten weeks behind me. So I just showed her what was going on. Victoria revealed that she also had a huge bump with Jack and looked nine months pregnant at the seven-month mark. Victoria said: It was just huge. People say with your second you do look bigger, but lots of people were asking meI was having twins.I suppose I was carrying the equivalent of that, roughly. It got to the point where even walking became quite hard.Trying to look after a one-year-old in that state is really dficult. Today, Jack wears the same size nappies as his one-year-old sister Emilie and is powering through her hand-me-downs. Victoria said: When Jack was born he was one of the biggest of his age in the country, he was in the th centile for weight. Because Jack was my second, I was a bit more prepared going to the birthing centre. I had some - month clothes for him to wear because he wouldnapost fit into newborn stuff. One issue we had though, was with nappies because none of the newborn sized ones at the centre fit him. story: Member of notorious neighbour from hell family dies of Covid in prisonJohn Pitt, whose family were known as Britains worst "neighbours from hell" after hitting the headlines in the s, died as he served a jail sentence at HMP Humber, east YorkshireJohn Pitt, whose family were known as Britains worst neighbours from hell Image: Hull Daily Mail   MEN MediaByHarry Ingham:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A member of one of Britainaposs most notorious families has died in prison after catching Covid.John Pitt, whose family were known as Britainaposs worst neighbours from hell after hitting the headlines in the s, died as he served a jail sentence at HMP Humber in east Yorkshire. An official report said Mr Pitt died aged  after falling victim to a huge Covid outbreak at the prison near South Cave on the outskirts of Hull.Mr Pitt died of Covid- on March , , aged .Hull Live reports that Mr Pitt, who was a serial criminal with a history of violence, had served almost eight years more than his original sentence after he was jailed for attacking a former partner.A judge had described him as an obvious and gross continuing danger to the public. Mr Pittaposs partner had been tied up naked and threw herself ft from a window to escape him when he attacked her out of the blue at their home in Northumberland, trying to gouge her eyes out and threatening to cut her throat with scissors.  In July , Mr Pitt was given a minimum four-and-a half year imprisonment for public protectionsentence for  imprisonment. He was moved to HMP Humber in . An independent investigation by the Prisons and Probations Ombudsman has found that Mr Pitt caught the disease in the prison during a apossignicant outbreakapos in February and March . The ombudsman said she was concerned that when Mr Pitt tested positive for Covid-, healthcare staff did not take his clinical observations and he was not monitored to seehe became symptomatic. Mr Pitt was obese, which meant that he was at a higher risk of developing complications, and should have been closely monitored and his observations taken regularly, the report says. Mr Pitt complained about being unwell on March  but was told by a nurse to sit down to improve his breathing. The nurse then said they wouldto check on him later. But the report said Mr Pittaposs condition and risk “should have prompted an urgent clinical response. The nurse did notfor over an hour, by which time Mr Pitt had got into bed because he felt so unwell, and then an ambulance was called”.  At hospital, Mr Pitt’s health deteriorated, and he was admitted to intensive care unit where he was put on a ventilator. He died almost three weeks later. The report said there were also concerns Mr Pitt’s diabetes was not monitored regularly and there were no follow up checks or reviews documented in his clinical record. Mr Pitt had a violent le along with an extensive criminal record, including numerous counts of assault, criminal damage, and drug dealing. The report said he was the sixth prisoner at HMP Humber to die since March , with one more having died since. Of the other deaths, one was drug-related, two were self-inflicted and three were from Covid-. Jailing him in , Mr Justice Openshaw described Mr Pitt’s criminal record as “appalling”, Chronicle Live reported. story: Pub owner says two families left venue like bomb site without paying £ billThe spokesperson for the White Horse Inn venue on Barnby Moor, in East Retford, said the four adults and their children were "intimidating" to the staff during their stayThe pub owner said the families left the place looking like a bomb site Image: White Horse InnByOlimpia Zagnat:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A devastated pub owner claims two families left his venue like a bomb site without paying their £ bill.The spokesperson for the White Horse Inn venue on Barnby Moor, in East Retford, said the four adults and their children arrived at the restaurant at around .pm, and were intimidating to the staff during their stay.They ordered tomahawk steaks, cocktails, vodka and drinks for their four children which rounded up to an impressive £.However, they reportedly vanished at around pm without paying. A spokesperson for the venue said this could not come at a worse time, as the business is still recovering from the Covid lockdown.He told Nottinghamshire Live: It is just ridiculous. One of them distracted the member of staff by standing at the bar out of sight of the door. He was ordering another drink while the ladies in the group marched their children out, one under each arm, and bundled them into a couple of cars. Then they waited until the last guy exited and shot off. He went on and said: We started the business in , just before Covid hit, and so obviously it is a dficult time. The price of everything is going up massively. We have got wholesale beer increases of nearly p a pint this year to deal with. We are going to try to soak that all up, and we will try and fight all of that and then people are going to do that. It is not very helpful.  He said that while the incident hit the venue from a business perspective, it is the well-being of members of the staff that he is more concerned about. He added: The member of the staff that was on rang the manager and said he was upset and quite exasperated. He had been intimidated by their passive-aggressive behaviour - and he has blamed himself. It is awful because he was doing really well and was training to be in a managerial position. Now he has lost all of his confidence. It is not that it just hurts my pocket, the real problem is that the staff there are nervous now and do not feel comfortable.  The pub owner said that he has worked in the industry for about a decade - but that he has never witnessed anything like it. He added: The children were running around the restaurant, running up to peopleaposs tables, falling over things. And then they have left bowls of food upturned on the floor - I have never seen anything like it in ten years in the industry. It was just like a pack of bears had been in.Inspector Hayley Crawford, of Nottinghamshire Police, said: “We are pursuing lines of enquiry following a report that a group of people had attended The White Horse Inn in Barnby Moor, eaten a meal and left without paying.“Officers are making enquiries after the incident was reported to us at around pm yesterday. “To help us with our investigation we are urging anyone with information to please get in touch with us.” It is believed those involved left the area in a white van and a black car. news uk-news six-times-queen-sent-secret-"Queen praises work of Charles and William in COP speechByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments They say actions speak louder than words - and it seems this is very much the case for the Queen. She rarely talks about her inner most thoughts and feelings, but sometimes instead uses her clothes, jewellery or even her surroundings to send what some believe are secret messages.Just this week while meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at Windsor Castle, and royal watchers were quick to point out the beautul blue and yellow flowers in the background.Of course yellow and blue are the colours of the Ukrainian flag and it was seen as a tribute to the people of the country amid the Russian invasion. So what other secret messages has she seemingly sent in recent years  Here we take a look... Ukraine flowers  The most recent subtle message was of course the the blue and yellow flowers on display at Windsor Castle during an audience with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.Mr Trudeau was in London earlier this week for talks on the war in Ukraine with Boris Johnson and Dutch counterpart Mark Rutte.Sources said that the small gesture of the flowers was a deliberate sign of the Queenaposs solidarity with the people of Ukraine.Later, at a press conference with Mr Johnson and Mr Rutte, Mr Trudeau confirmed he talked to Her Majesty about Ukraine. He explained: I can tell you in my conversation with her this morning she was as insightful and perspicacious as ever, very interested in whataposs going on. Brexit hat Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. In , the Queen attended the State Opening of Parliament wearing a vibrant blue hat that featured yellow flowers.At that time the debate surrounding the aftermath of the Brexit vote was raging in the UK and in her speech, which is written by the government, she outlined how the country was preparing to exit the EU. However, many people on social media couldnapost help but notice that her hat very much resembled that of the European Union flag.In , in her book The Other Side of the Coin: The Queen, the Dresser and the Wardrobe, the Queen dresser Angela Kelly insisted it never occurred to her the hat resembled the flag. Anniversary brooch During last yearaposs deeply personal Christmas message, the Queen paid an extraordinary tribute to her late beloved husband Prince Philip. Pinned to her dress was a stunning sapphire chrysanthemum brooch that royal fans pointed out she wore on many happy times with the Duke of Edinburgh - believing it was a tribute to him. Among the times she wore the brooch was on her honeymoon in  and to mark her rd wedding anniversary in . Red boxes Just last month, an image of a beaming Queen was released to mark Her Majestyaposs Platinum Jubilee year. It shows her at Sandringham going through papers from her red box, which she is sent everyday from the Government. And according to former royal butler Grant Harrold, it was signicant the boxes were included in the snap. He said on Tik Tok: People keep asking me do I think the Queen is going to continue with her work  Well in this photograph you see one of her official government boxes and of course this is the Queen doing her day to day work. I think this shows all of us that even though sheaposs now coming into her th year, sheaposs been on the throne  years, she is very much going to continue being a monarch. Lockdown message brooch  One of the most important address the Queen has given to the country in the past two years came in April .In it, she spoke of the unprecedented nature of the Covid pandemic being fought around the globe and promised we will meet again despite lockdown.For the speech, the Queen wore a beautul turquoise and diamond brooch that once belonged to her grandmother Queen Mary. It was later pointed out that stone is said to be one that promotes healing and love as well as enhances the powers of leadership. Cop outfit Last November, a bout of ill health meant the Queen had to pull out of attending the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow.However, she recorded a rousing video message where she urged world leaders to help protect the planet.For the speech, she wore a green dress, which is of course the colour of being environmentally friendly. She paired it with a rare a diamond and ruby butterfly which was gted to her upon her engagement to Prince Philip. And many believed it was her subtle way of paying tribute to her late husband, who had been heavily involved in environmental matters. title: uber driver gets wedged crevice
story: Uber driver gets wedged in crevice after blindly following sat-nav through countrysideWhen he ordered his sat nav to take him back in the direction of the A, the machine directed its driver through darkness and down a steep path across the Saddleworth MoorThe car lying abandoned on a rocky hillside near Huddersfield Image: Cavendish PressLtdByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsAn Uber driver on his way home from dropping off a customer blindly following his sat nav through the countryside and became wedged in a crevice. The driver had dropped off a customer in Marsden, a village near Huddersfield in Yorkshire, and was heavily relying on his navigation system upon turning around. When he ordered his sat nav to take him back in the direction of the A, the machine directed its driver through darkness and down a steep path across the Saddleworth Moor. The path was narrow and littered with sharp rocks, but the persistent driver carried on until his car, a Mercedes Vito, ground to a halt.He reportedly tried in vain to reverse, but eventually gave up and called friends for a lt home. He made sure he walked to an accessible road, first. Bemused locals surveying the scene the next day presumed the vehicle had been stolen then dumped by joyriders. That was until the embarrassed Uber driver then ed and revealed the truth about what had happened.  Local Craig Hannah said it was “amazing” that the driver managed to get that far along the “rough and very steep” track. “Apparently he had been working in the area late on Saturday night and was trying toto base,” she said. “A passenger did say he could drive down the lane even though there was a sign warning that it was unsuitable for vehicles. “If you were local you would know the road is not passable but this guy was clearly out of town and didn’t know.” Craig had heard the driver had become so stuck that he had not been able to get his door open. The back bumper of the driver’s car had been ripped off, he said, with the only way to retrieve it, likely being dragging it back up the hill. Craig said the driver seemed a “really nice guy” who had been left shell shocked by the experience. A less sympathetic local said: ‘We heard the taxi driver was just blindly following his satnav and got stuck. ‘Some people just don’t learn from the old adage – the computer is not always right.’ The Uber driver is reportedly awaiting repair costs, after the vehicle was rescued by a tow truck on Monday. story: UK Covid cases rise by % in a week as hospitalisations and deaths also spikeThe UK has seen a massive % rise in Covid cases in a week while hospitalisations and deaths have also risen sharply since the government announced Freedom Day last monthCovid cases have gone up by % Image: Amer Ghazzal REX ShutterstockByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments The UK has has seen a huge spike in Covid cases with % more on Wednesday than a week earlier while hospitalisations and deaths have also risen sharply.New figures show that , people tested positive for the virus in the past  hours, compared to , last Wednesday, according to @UKCOVIDStats - this is an increase of %. According to the same site, a total of  people have died from in the past  hours from Covid after testing positive in the past  days, up from  this time last week, which is a % increase in deaths. The rises come following Freedom Day in the UK at the end of February with the government having laid out plans for the country to start living with Covid and abandoning restrictions.Government figures show , people tested positive for coronavirus between March  and March  - an increase of .% compared to the previous seven-day period, reported YorkshireLive.  According to the gov.uk website, , people were in hospital with Covid on March , with  patients requiring a mechanical ventilator.The worrying figures come just weeks before the government plans to scrap free lateral flow tests for most people on April .Free PCR tests will also not be available to people with coronavirus symptoms as the government implements its aposLiving with Covidapos plan.People over the age of  and those with weakened immune systems will still be eligible for free lateral flow tests. Free testing will also be available for social care workers and NHS staff with symptoms.The government may scrap all Covid travel restrictions within days under new plans being discussed by ministers.  While the passenger locator form has been simplied, it remains a requirement for people heading back to the UK from holidays and could be removed completely. Travelling has become more straight forward in recent months for people who have been vaccinated and they no longer need to take Covid tests before departure and then on theirto the UK. And also under discussion for ministers will be the possible removal of the testing requirements for the unvaccinated.  The removal of the passenger locator form could be a boost for the tourism industry ahead of the Easter holidays which is reportedly the aim of Transport Secretary Grant Shapps.The forms were introduced two years ago as a means of tracking infections and went into signicant detail at a time when travellers had to quarantine on theirto the UK. Currently the form is a lot more simple and requires people’s address, contact number and flight details. title: uk schools should ban sausages
story: UK schools should ban sausages, bacon and milk from menus to keep kids healthyTop doctors said meat and dairy should be wiped from the canteen menu which would benefit kids health, help the climate and save the NHS up to £ billionMeaty meals could be swapped for alternatives like chickpea curry and lentil bolognese Image: Getty ImagesByLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Doctors are calling for bacon, sausages and milk to be banned from school menus to help keep children healthy. Instead schoolchildren should be given vegan meals at lunch which doctors say will tackle obesity and help the environment. Bacon and sausages could be swapped with lentil bolognese and chickpea curry while cows milk could be replaced with a vegan alternative, one expert suggests.Dr Shireen Kassam, leading the campaign, told The Sun it is vital that families start making better food choices and see the plus sides of the diet. The founder of Plant Based Health Professionals also warned that eating meat and dairy could have a detrimental effect on youngstersapos health. Reports suggest that one in four primary school aged children have obesity while one in three do not eat even one portion of vegetables per day.  Dr Kassam said: Swapping current school meal plans for plant-based meals makes fruit and vegetables more accessible, but also ensures that children are eating nutritious foods daily, optimising their health and minimising health-related issues.Meat and dairy have proven to be detrimental to children’s health, including increasing cholesterol and blood pressure, increased risk of heart disease and is linked to the cause of some cancers. Obesity in children and young people is a severely concerning health problem, and one we could so easily tackle through plant-based nutrition and education. Dr Kassam told of the importance of a whole-food plant-based diet where children would be free from low saturated fat and benefit from vitamins and minerals, fibre and antioxidants. If the UKaposs . million schoolchildren swapped one meat meal for a plant-based alternative, greenhouse gas emissions would drop by . tonnes which is the equivalent of taking , cars off the road each year.Dr Kassam, a consultant haematologist at Londonaposs King’s College Hospital, said that the NHS could also benefit and save around £ billionBrits ditched meat and dairy.Some schools have already taken the decision to drop meat from the canteen menu. Our Lady of Sion in Worthing, East Sussex, and Barrowford Primary School, near Nelson, Lancashire, are already meat-free.  But some parents have criticised the move and said the dramatic change is absolutely ridiculous. Questions have been raised over the right to have freedom of choice and why schools had to dictate their childrenaposs diets. But Dr Kassam said: Schools need to lead on ways to tackle both health and climate issues and educating around. Introducing plant-based nutrition is key to doing this. story: UKs oldest nightclub famous for sticky carpet is selling floor for £ a pieceYorkshires iconic The Acapulco nightclub in Halax has always been known for its cheap booze and grim flooring - and now clubbers can have a piece of their favourite venue to keep foreverThe Acapulco is one of West Yorkshires most loved nightclubs - and now you can own a piece of its legendary carpet Image: Acapulco   SWNSByAshley PembertonSam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Britainaposs oldest nightclub famed for its notorious booze-soaked sticky carpet is selling off chunks of its vintage flooring to nostalgic revellers.The -year-old Acapulco in Halax, West Yorkshire, is known to punters for its distinctive, swirly-patterned adhesive floor as much as for its p drinks offers. Clubbers now have the chance to buy a souvenir section of the sticky rug with prices ranging from £ for an A sized piece to £ for a larger, framed piece.Owner Simon Jackson was inspired after hearing a young clubber celebrating his th birthday tell how his parents met at the club and his grandmother had worked there. Now, having been on sale for just a day, it has sold more than  pieces already and raised £, for the local Street Angels charity, which helps homeless people.  Owner Simon Jackson said: It started as a bit of a joke, I had a conversation with a lad celebrating his th and he said his grandmother used to work there and his mother met his father there. There were three generations of the same family celebrating. The mother said aposI remember the carpet, it is the same one apos and I said it probably is.I told her changing the carpet has been on the list of things to do for a few years but things kept getting in the way. They said aposwe should take a piece of it as itaposs part of their family history and a few other people said theyaposd take a piece. We got to thinking how many people have met here and had first kisses, birthdays whatever here. The joke quickly snowballed and Simon - who worked as a DJ in the early s before buying the club in  - decided to cut some pieces and sell them to punters. He added: We knew Street Angels were struggling for money so we thought weaposd try to get some money for them as they donapost get any funding. Sales went live at .pm on Wednesday and by .pm weaposd sold over  pieces. By pm that night weaposd raised over £, for the charity so hopefully we can get a few thousand for them. If weaposd got a couple of hundred quid weaposd have been happy. Itaposs just blown up, we couldnapost cope with the demand. Weaposve had to dig it out of the skip and clean it up to sell the rest of it. The club has been a staple of nightle in the former mill town since  and generations have walked on its infamous carpet for more than  years. Simon added: Itaposs famous for three things being really old, selling drinks for p and the carpet. It doesnapost even look that bad, itaposs just going thin in places. The club has created a grid-like map for anyone interested in buying a piece of the carpet - so they can identy the specic spot they would like. Simon added: It would be greatpeople could buy the spot of the carpet where they had their first kiss or they first met. It has been a bitterly cold start to March for many parts of the UK with temperatures hovering around the low single figures but there will now be a brief respite from the wintry conditions - although it may be too soon to say spring has arrived. With temperatures set to peak at C or even C, it will be warmer than Athens which is predicted to be C on Thursday or Monaco where it will be C.After several cold nights, the weather has become increasingly unsettled this week as a low pressure front threatens from the Atlantic and is competing with high pressure over the continent. The will also be a east-west ide, with the higher temperatures on the east coast. Met Office spokesman Richard Miles told The Sun : The west will be wet and windy which will gradually spread across the country overnight, and then it will be cooler in the west and wetter in the east. Thataposs the picture for the next few days. It will be wet and windy over the weekend too but when the sun comes out in central and eastern areas, we will see temperatures creeping up to quite pleasant numbers. BBC weather forecaster Stav Danaos said that there will be sunshine especially across the east of England.Cold, frosty start for Northern Ireland but bright with some sunshine, he said. Very mild across eastern and southeast England where some sunny spells are possible. Patchy rain reaches southern England later. Tonight: Cloud and patchy light rain moving northwards across some parts, though also some dry spells. Breezy and mild. Heavy rain reaching the far southwest later. Friday: Patchy rain clearing northern and eastern parts to leave a brighter spell. Rain in the southwest, heavy at times, moving northeastwards across most parts. Windy, with coastal gales. Outlook for Saturday to Monday: An unsettled weekend with showers or longer spells of rain, wettest in the west. Windy for a time with coastal gales in the west. Drier for most on Monday. title: woman sneaks london fashion week
story: Woman sneaks into London Fashion Week wearing bin bag and banana peel found on floorEllie Marie Whitby, from Liverpool, came up with the funny idea for her YouTube Channel and says she even found an old banana peel on the floor to add to the trash lookEllie Marie Whitby has shared how she snuck into London Fashion Week wearing just a bin bag Image: Ellie Marie WhitbyByAaliyah RuggAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsA woman shares how she snuck into London Fashion Week wearing just a bin bag. Ellie Marie Whitby, from Liverpool, came up with the “funny idea” for her YouTube Channel. London Fashion Week takes place in the capital twice a year, showcasing hundreds of designers to a global audience. Ellie, who previously managed to persuade her mum to dress up as Bigfoot stalking the woodlands of West Kirby, said she looked forward to the challenge. She managed to get into an event after calling multiple buildings in London and hoping one designer would reveal their secret location.She told the ECHO: “I just try to make comedy and funny challenges for my content. Something light-hearted to make people smile and I thought this would be a funny idea.“At first it looked pretty terrible, I stuck my head through a hole and it was awful. I haven’t got any arts and craft skills but eventually, I managed to make it look half decent.” Ellie even found an old banana peel on the floor to add to the “trash look”. She said: “Originally, London Fashion Week is held in one big event building but for security reasons, every single catwalk had been moved to a secret location.“I spent the entire day with my friend in a coffee shop calling every event building in London. A lot of designers wouldn’t give us the address because we weren’t on the list but one slipped up. “We turned up and my friend pretended to be a paparazzi taking pictures of me.” Ellie claims she “joined the queue” and followed the lead of the girl in front of her.The YouTuber added: “They were already running behind schedule. It was such a surreal experience, to be ushered in and sat there in a bin bag. “A woman ended up coming over to me and asking uswe wanted to sit with her on the front row seats. “I was definitely getting some judgemental looks but I felt a bit like a celebrity. It felt weird to be getting papped at a prestigious event. “People loved the video. My fans said it’s a favourite because it’s so homemade and I managed to get in. “I’ve always loved creating videos and messing around with friends and it’s just grown. “But I just did this one on a whim, I’ve never had an interest in attending London Fashion Week before but now I have.”The full video can be found on Ellieaposs YouTube channel. title: woman struggling breathe urine soaked
story: Woman is struggling to breathe in urine soaked, flea-ridden council homeSarah Keenan and her disabled partner say the property at Tencreek in Looe is unfit for humans as she "struggles to breathe" inside due to urine and a stench of sweat at the homeSarah Keenan has said the property is not fit for humans Image: Cornwall Live   BPM MediaByChris MatthewsTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsA woman has told how she is struggling to breathe due to the stench at her flea-ridden council property which she claims is unfit for humans to live in.Sarah Keenan and her disabled partner say the property at Tencreek in Looe is unfit for any human to live in. She said that the couple have had to contend with flea bites, a bodily fluid stained mattress and a foul stench among other complaints, reported CornwallLive. It is so bad they are sleeping on a mattress on the lounge floor. Sarah said: “It really is awful. The property is flea-ridden, the settee is broken in half, the toilet is disgusting, the bed is black with body fluid and the stench is foul. The bed is horrible and stained with urine and sweat.  She said that the conditions are having a bad impact on her partneraposs mental health. “My partner is disabled and suffers with his mental health really badly. This is just making it worse. He’s also severely epileptic and this is making his fits even worse, Sarah continued. “Nobody can seem to help and despite calling the council loads of times I’m just not getting anywhere. I’m struggling to breathe here. “It is so bad here my daughter came to stay but has since gone back with my mother in law as she just can’t stay here.”  Sarah says she ended up in temporary accommodation after the landlord of her privately rented property sold up. She then lived in sheltered accommodation in Bude before being moved to Tencreek. A member of staff at Tencreek did reportedly use a ‘flea bomb’ in one of the rooms, but Sarah says it hasn’t done anything to help. She added: “I don’t know how long we’re here for but so far nothing at all has been done to help and we can’t go on living like this.” Cornwall Council has been contacted for comment. title: archeologists discover worlds first city
story: Archeologists discover worlds ‘first city in old spy satellite imagesExcited anthropologist Dr Jesse Casana feels the breakthrough could unlock some important secrets about Tell Brak, which he claims is around , years older than the Ancient Egyptian pyramidsDr Jesse Casana first saw the worlds ‘first city called Tell Brak in spy satellites Image: Smithsonian Channel WSByCharlie PittockSam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments An archeologist who believes he may have discovered the worldaposs ‘first cityapos thanks to incredible images taken by an old spy satellite has spoken of his excitement.The area, claimed to be , years older than the Ancient Egyptian pyramids, is called Tell Brak.Anthropologist Dr Jesse Casana believes the find could be a great breakthrough and may unlock some important information, report Express. The expert has dedicated several years studying the old spy photographs of the Middle East. His work has even featured in documentary ‘The Le of Earth: The Age of Humans’ - and says the snaps from  years ago could hold some very important answers. Dr Casana feels the images are invaluable because the countryside in the Middle East was far less industrialised when they were taken.  He said: “We were able to document something like , previously unknown archaeological sites that, through the history of  years of archaeologists working in the Middle East, no one had ever documented.” Having started as a small settlement in the seventh millennium BC, Tell Brak evolved during the fourth millennium BC into one of the biggest cities in Upper Mesopotamia.That included parts of northwestern Iraq, northeastern Syria and southeastern Turkey. A small settlement first emerged at the site in circa  BC, with pottery found at the site dating back to then. Excavations and surface surveys have revealed that Tell Brak developed as an urban hub slightly before better known cities in southern Mesopotamia such as Uruk.  It grew to around  hectares by the late fth millennium BC, and had more than doubled in size to  hectares in the period spanning  BC to  BC. Tell Brak expanded again around  BC, when it became known as Nagar, and served as the capital of a regional kingdom. For a settlement like Tell Brak to appear as it did, the environment needed to have been transformed by some form of dramatic event. The last ice age ended around , years ago, causing the Earth’s climate to change radically. The planet was at its warmest point in , years. Where Tell Brak lies is an area of the Middle East known as the Fertile Crescent, the culmination of the ice age allowed this area to finally become fertile. Rainfall and temperatures increased, leading to a great expansion of grassland, and climate change fuelled a food revolution.Rainfall and temperatures increased, leading to a great expansion of grassland, and climate change fuelled a food revolution. For millennia, humans had foraged wild grass seeds, but now, wheat and barley proved easy to grow and to control. Ancient humans began to settle and to nurture and protect their crops. These people started to abandon their hunter-gatherer lestyle, instead opting to become farmers. Human reliance on cultivated plants and domesticated animals changed the landscape forever from this point. These settled populations expanded, overwhelming the remaining hunter-gatherers, and transformed the landscape with their fields, villages, towns and eventually cities. A ‘tell’, in Middle Eastern archaeology, is a raised mound marking the site of an ancient city. In ancient times, houses were built from mud, which would crumble easily when exposed to the elements. Earlier debris would be levelled off in the rebuilding process and new buildings would be erected on top, so most tells are typically shaped like a low truncated cone. At over  metres high, and  by  metres in area, Tell Brak — or Nagar as it was then — is one of the largest in the area. It is believed to have thrived under dferent peoples right up until circa  BC when it was destroyed by the Assyrians. title: little girl beautiful voice made
story: Little girl with beautul voice made the world weep for children of UkraineThere has never been a more powerful version of Let It Go, Polly Hudson says of the footage from an underground bunker, reminding us how lives have been turned upside down for millions of innocentsAmelia singing in the bunker Image: PAopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Mar |commentsIt’s the chaos surrounding her that you notice first. The ­desperate families squeezed in, standing, sitting, lying wherever they can, next to their precariously piled ­belongings, packed into the dank underground space they now call home. There’s an air of restlessness, a palpable sense of tension and anxiety. How could there not be And then, completely unexpectedly, something magical happens. Little Amelia – age unknown, but probably, what, seven or eight  – stands up on a chair. She’s wearing a sparkly jumper with stars on it, from HM a few years ago – my friend’s daughter has the same one and still loves it too. Hands clenched together shyly, unbrushed hair pulled back into a ponytail, Amelia plucks up all her courage, opens her mouth and starts to sing Let It Go, from Frozen. And like a spell cast in the movie her song comes from, the Kyiv shelter falls silent. Everyone turns and gives this small blonde scrap of a girl their mesmerised full attention. No one moves. Babies stop crying. This captive audience cannot take their eyes off her, as they listen to her sweet, steady voice, a chink of shining light in the unimaginable ­darkness of Ukraine.She has given these people the gt of focusing on something other than the living nightmare they’re enduring, albeit briefly, and there isn’t a dry eye in the room. Or from any of the millions around the globe who have since watched the video on social media.Despite probably never having heard Ukrainian before, the song is in the universal language of Disney, kids from any country in the world watching it could name that tune in three. In the caption, the woman who posted it explains that Amelia told her she wanted to be “a singer on a grand stage” – an ambition now fulfilled, just not in a way anyone would want. Their poor parents can, at least, try to fight back, but the children of Ukraine are utterly defenceless in this war. Putin is torturing and traumatising these pure, faultless human beings, turning them into orphans. Murdering  of them.  Amelia and the other kids in that shelter, and similar ones across the country. Danya and Mpak, the boys trapped in Calais, denied entry by our callous government because they don’t have the right paperwork. The -year-old who braved a -mile journey to safety alone. Heroic President Volodymyr Zelensky’ s own children – Aleksandra, , and Kiril, age nine – who have targets on their backs. Polina, the girl with the pink hair, and her brother Semyon, both dead. And the many other nameless young casualties.All entirely blameless, innocent children – just like their entirely blameless, innocent mums and dads – frightened for their lives.  Two weeks ago they were moaning about homework, playing with their friends, not eating their vegetables. Now, suddenly plunged into a reality where growing up without their fathers may well be the best case scenario. The least worst of their horrendous options. When Let It Go lyricist Kristen Anderson-Lopez saw Amelia’s rendition, she tweeted: “Dear Little Girl with the beautul voice, my husband and I wrote this song. The way you sing it is like a magic trick that spreads the light in your heart and heals everyone who hears it.” She finished by urging Amelia to “Keep singing!” If only that choice was hers. title: lunar rover sends back never
story: Lunar rover sends back never-before-seen pictures of far side of the MoonThe panoramic shot of the far side of the Moon, sometimes known as the dark side, was taken by the rover known as Yutu , now in its third year of lunar explorationThe picture beamed back to Earth by Yutu  of the far side of the Moon Image: NASA GSFC Arizona State UniversityByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A Moon rover which has spent the last three years investigating unknown areas of the Moon has beamed back a never before seen view of the Earth’s lunar cousin. The incredible image was released by Ourspace, part of the Chinese National Space Administration.The beautul panoramic shot shows the recent journey taken by the rover, known as Yutu , on the hidden hemisphere of the lunar surface. The lbs solar-powered rover landed atop of the Changapose  lander in January .Its powerful cameras recently detected a “mystery hut” - which transpired to be a rabbit-shaped rock- so went to investigate.When it looked back its tracks were clearly shown in the dust on the surface. A diary entry by the Yutu  team said: “On the moonlit night, the scientists expressed their desire to explore the cornucopia.  “ This task seems simple, and the image shows that the road is smooth. However, after the terrain products are actually generated, the drivers still scratch their heads. “An insurmountable obstacle area lights up the red light for this road, although the range is not large, but it cuts off the way of direct detection. “However, this is not dficult for the experienced Yutu drivers. “It started smoothly, turned perfectly, stopped in time, and the detection was successful. Soon Yutu completed the set detection task and ed safely. The pilots applauded each other and looked forward to the valuable scientic data brought back by the probe.”The Earth only sees one side of the Moon with all six of Nasa’s manned Apollo missions landing on the near side. The far side, sometimes wrongly called the dark side, remained a mystery until the Chinese rover successfully landed and started investigations. Yutu  and the Changapose  lander have both far exceeded their original letimes of around three months and one year respectively. Sara Russell, at the Natural History Museum in London, previously said: “The exploration of the far side is really in its infancy. “It’s like this whole new world to explore. We really have a lot to find out about the far side of the Moon. “It’s really exciting.”  It comes as it was announced Artemis , the first in NASAaposs new generation of Moon missions, has been delayed until May, possibly June. It was due to lt off from Kennedy Space Center in Florida in April but has been put back until the space agency has more data from a full rehearsal. Artemis  will take an uncrewed mission around the Moon and back before future missions land on the lunar surface. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. title: winter olympian kirsty muir on her surreal beijing experience and ambitions for the 2026 games
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: march gardening tips it starts with a seed
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIn a week or two it will be March, which will hopefully bring some sunny days to tempt gardeners back into the garden # and many of us are really aching for spring now.This is the month for sowing seeds and getting the garden ready for the summer.But, before you rush to get sowing, take time to plan what you want to grow, how many plants you are going to need and when you want them to flower or bear fruit. This is particularly good advice for anyone with a veg plot.A sowing plan of what seeds and how many to sow each month is key to successful growing and means you won#t be throwing out unwanted seedlings and that your flower and veg beds will be full all year round.A word of warning about sowing direct into the ground at this time of year there may be a few sunny days to enjoy outside but the soil can still be chilly, making germination and survival hard.Sowing indoors is a better option. Not only does it provide a warm environment for germination, but seeds and seedlings are easier to protect from pests. If you can find some environmentally sound sowing trays and containers, rather than using plastic, that#s even better. Paper and cardboard pots can be packed snugly in a tray which avoids over handling and makes them easy to water.Small seeds should be scattered sparingly on the surface of compost filled seed trays then covered with a sprinkling of sieved compost. If the seeds are big enough to handle, you can sow them inidually into cm pots. The quantity should be according to the instructions specied on the seed packet, but usually for small seeds between five and  seeds per pot. For plants that grow long roots, such as peas or beans, you can put them into a compost filled cardboard toilet roll tube and, once ready, they can be planted outside, tube and all.Most seeds will germinate and grow in a warm setting such as a greenhouse, cold frame or on a sunny windowsill. You should keep them damp by using a mist spray to start with before moving onto a watering can with a fine rose nozzle.Once the seedlings have grown their second pair of leaves and before they get too squashed in seed trays or pots, pot them on into small pots. Simply ease out a clump of seedlings with an old cutlery fork or dibber and # handling only the leaves to avoid damaging delicate stems and roots # gently tease them apart. Drop inidual seedlings into a five-centimetre compost filled newspaper pot ensuring the lower leaves are above the compost level. Once you see roots appearing from the bottom of the pot, it’s time to pot on to a bigger pot before planting outside once the weather and soil warms up.If you are growing your own veg, now is a good time to sow first early potatoes. These can be planted from mid-March, however planting times will y across the country according to temperature and risk of frost. Early potatoes grow well in the ground and in containers such as potato grow bags or old compost bags. You should plant your chitted potatoes with the shoots facing upwards in soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter, approximately cms deep and cms apart.Once stems are about cms tall, they will need earthing up by drawing soil around them to create a cm high ridge, to protect against frost and keep growing potatoes covered. Good ieties of early potatoes are: Swt # good for containers, white skinned and white fleshed Annabelle # nutty flavour with firm waxy yellow flesh and Maris Bard # white flesh with good #new potato# flavour and drought resistance.Spring seems tantalisingly close in March, particularly as work in the garden starts to get going again.According to the Royal Horticultural Society, spring usually arrives by mid-March and the frequent sunny days provide the opportunity for an increasing range of gardening tasks. It#s time to get busy preparing seed beds, sowing seed, cutting back winter shrubs and generally tidying up around the garden.Top three jobs in March:PICS:Once the seedlings have grown their second pair of leaves and before they get too squashed in seed trays or pots, pot them on into small pots. no_aGardening_March

title: back to nature at inveraray history society
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowInveraray History Society took a walk on the wild side at its latest meeting as Argyll Estates# head stalker set his sights on an entertaining evening.Tom Kirsop provided society members with an informative and imaginative talk at their February gathering, covering his work and experiences on the local estate.Growing up in Clydebank, Tom had always had an interest in animals and moved to Argyll as a forest ranger in Dalmally.Since starting to work with Argyll Estates, which he thoroughly enjoys, Tom has been able to develop his work with animals in many dferent ways.In Queen Victoria’s time the current ,-acre estate was on an even bigger scale and has witnessed a huge increase in the number of deer since then.This has been due to the lack of any natural predators and, with further planting of trees since the s, the deer have had more protective covering.Modern inventions such as drones and the use of argocats, have made it easier for people working on estates to estimate numbers of deer more accurately and to be able to meet the necessary annual targets of keeping the deer population to manageable levels.Working on the estate also involves a range of other projects, such as collecting data on golden eagles, barn owls, making fishing available at the Glen Shira dam and taking clients out stalking.More recently Tom has started up West Highland Wildle Tours to give people of all ages a real insight into the wildle and beautul scenery on our doorstep.For the society#s March meeting, Ken MacTaggart will give a presentation about #The Medieval Pilgrim Way to Loch Awe#.The venue will be Inveraray church hall on Tuesday March , starting at .pm.Everyone is welcome. Please follow the Inveraray and District History Society on Facebook for our latest news.

GHK broke the deadlock to score the first try of the game  minutes into the game, then missed the conversion.Mid Argyll then put together some great attacking plays and earned a penalty just outside the GHK -metre line.Inside centre Coll MacKay stepped up to score Mid Argyll#s first points of the campaign with a glorious conversion.  –  to GHK.GHK went on to score two more tries and one conversion # before disaster struck for Mid Argyll on the stroke of half time and with the score at  –  to GHK, as Wilson hobbled off with suspected knee ligament damage.With Wilson playing out of position in the front row, Mid Argyll had to reshuffle an already patchwork pack with Aaron McAllister moving from the wing to hooker and usual hooker Robbie Herd moving to prop.The new look front row finished off, Daniel Doherty doing well, as they held their own against an experienced opposition pack.Mid Argyll took time to settle into the new system, though, and GHK ran in two more converted tries.Mid Argyll almost produced the perfect reply when fly-half Logan Allen whipped a quick ball out to Gritten who, without actually catching the ball, flicked it on to Innes Patterson.Patterson beat two players and released Ed King-Venables who was caught by the GHK defence just short of the line.GHK ran the ball back up field but some great defensive play from flanker Gordon McLean, Self and MacArthur stopped them on the halfway line.A scrum to Mid Argyll saw scrum-half Calum Patterson pick the ball from the feet of McLean and, noticing a gap in the defence, broke through.He still had two more players to beat before he ran over the whitewash for Mid Argyll#s first try of the season # undoubtedly try of the match. MacKay converted for another two points and the score was  –  GHK.Having played with no subs, fatigue was starting to set in for the Argyll boys and with GHK using their subs they ran in a few more breakaway tries.Towards the end of the game GHK had one last attempt and broke through the Argyll defence, but from nowhere C Patterson found the determination and energy to chase the attacker down and fling out an arm to ankle tap him five metres short of the line and supporting was Lochlain Ellis to compete for the ball and earn Mid Argyll a deserved penalty.The final whistle sounded shortly after and the game finished  - to GHK.Mid Argyll enjoyed great hospitality from hosts GHK and Innes Patterson was awarded man of the match before the long journey home.

The sight of the Ukranian people desperately seeking safety in neighbouring countries evokes scenes in Europe from the Second World War, as Hitler#s forces advanced, and later refugee crises sparked by the more recent Balkan conflict.As reported in this edition the women, children and elderly are heading in one direction # while the young men, and no doubt plenty of women too, are going the opposite way to defend their country from Putin.In the midst of such suffering and bravery, it is heartening to hear of so many Argyll folk joining a huge Europe-wide effort to help those forced to flee their homes.We would encourage our readers to support this cause in whatever way you can. No matter what happens next, the need for aid is going to be there for a long time to come.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Beginning later this month, the Let#s Make pottery studio in Lochgilphead is offering the chance for people to express their inner potter.Ceramic skills classes will be held at the Lochnell Street studio covering throwing, slab building, coiling and pinch pots as well as learning the #alchemy# of glazing.One-to-one support from an experienced ceramicist will be available in a relaxed atmosphere.Once participants# ceramics have been fired and glazed there will be the chance to show them off to friends and family at a special exhibition in the studio, with drinks and nibbles provided.The classes are due to begin on March .Email info@letsmakepottery to book or for more details.Plans for a wind turbine on the ridge of hills between Strachur and St Catherines have been unanimously rejected by councillors after fears were raised over the turbines# effect on tourism.Creag Dubh Renewables LLP had submitted plans to Argyll and Bute Council for nine turbines, which would have been positioned above Loch Fyne opposite Inveraray.But the authority#s planning, protective services and licensing committee unanimously rejected the proposal, in line with a planning officer’s recommendation.Despite two councillors disagreeing with concerns over visual impact, no amendment to the recommendation was offered at the committee’s virtual meeting on Wednesday, February .A planning officer had previously said in a handling report: #The proposal would result in a signicant adverse effect on some of the special landscape qualities of Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park and, consequently, the objectives of the designation and the overall integrity of the area would be compromised.Kintyre councillor Rory Colville asked: #How visible will this be on a clear day from the likes of the Cobbler, which is very popular #Planning officer Sandra Davies said: #It would be visible from the top of the Cobbler. I have been to the top and it gives you a wide, open view, and introducing a permanent wind farm may affect the view that people would look for.#The recommendation to refuse was unanimously agreed, with no amendments put forward.Campbeltown Grammar School now has a clearer sense of direction and higher confidence, education chiefs have said in a report.But inspectors have also said there has been #not yet any signicant evidence# of improved attainment at the school since the last visit by Education Scotland # though the watchdog says this is due to insufficient time for measures to take effect.A report has been published on a follow-up visit to the school by inspectors, who found many positives since the appointment of acting head teacher Sam Stewart.However, Education Scotland will request a further interim report from Argyll and Bute Council in six months, and will conduct further analysis in a year’s time.The inspector said: #Senior leaders integrated the school’s targets for recovery within the much-improved school improvement plan.#Recent signicant improvements in leadership have created a positive climate for learning, boosting morale among young people, staff and the wider community.#The school had refreshed its vision, values and aims responding to the area for improvement in the original report.#Further work is needed to ensure the school’s values provide a full and accurate reflection of its unique context.#The school now demonstrates a clear and convincing sense of direction. The community’s pride and confidence in the school has improved.“The acting head teacher has provided strong strategic leadership since her appointment in August , with important contributions from the local authority.#The impact of her leadership in school improvement planning, self-evaluation and staff professional learning is evident across the school.#Senior staff are highly visible around the school, promoting a calm and orderly environment. All staff are members of a school improvement group taking forward identied key areas.#The report, however, added: #Senior leaders recognise the fundamental need to improve learning, teaching and assessment to a more consistently high standard, as a key to raising attainment#They have taken well-judged steps to address areas of weakness, but these steps have had too little time to achieve signicant impact.#There is not yet any signicant evidence of overall improvement in attainment since the original inspection.#Overall, young people in the senior phase attain less well than those with comparable backgrounds across Scotland. However, on leaving school, almost all young people progress to positive destinations.#Members of Cupar Sub Aqua Club from Fe took time in mid-February to clear litter from the access route and surrounding areas at the fisherman#s car park on the shores of Loch Long.A club spokesperson said: #The site was in a terrible mess, however a concerted effort by four club members soon saw a huge improvement.#A round of applause to Stephen McGinn, Hannah McGinn, Ray Trueland and James Rimmer.#

story: Dorothy H CrawfordUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowMost of us are active by day and rest by night, but within these confines there are several possibilities ranging from larksto owls .These preferences, called chronotypes, have a genetic basis that controls one#s biological clock, but this can be modied by ious factors such as light exposure, age and lestyle.However, when the genetic and environmental cues are not aligned a chronic condition known as #social jetlag# may ensue.This problem is exacerbated during adolescence when chronotypes become increasingly delayed, but schools start early in the morning.This can cause sleep loss that may lead to major health and psychological problems and also affect academic performance.In a recent study scientists examined how the interaction between chronotype and school start time influenced inidual academic performance* by taking advantage of a high school system where  students had been randomly assigned to lessons in the morning , afternoonor evening .This enabled the unbiased testing of the effect of chronology and school schedules on academic performance in adolescents aged - years and - years.The results showed that among the early morning group, very few students got adequate sleep.The larksoutperformed owlsin all school subjects and this effect, which increased as students progressed through the school, was most extreme in maths.This outcome, however, was not evident in those having afternoon schooling, and the situation almost reversed in those receiving evening schooling, where students with later chronotypes performed slightly better in languages than the early chronotypes in the same group.Clearly academic performance is influenced by biological iation in daily rhythms, to an extent that has previously been underestimated.The study authors, while conceding that it is impractical to attempt to fully align school timetables to inidual chronotypes, suggest that it may be possible to, for example, progressively delay school start times during adolescence.* Goldin et al.  https:doi.org . s---.

title: france-currently-best-team-world-murrayfield-performance-suggests-yes
story: FRANCE lived up to the pre-match assessment of Scotland’s head coach Gregor Townsend as currently the best team in the world.BT Murrayfield was in fine voice as captain Rachel Malcolm and centre Helen Nelson – fresh from their - victory over Columbia in Dubai yesterday, which ensured qualication for the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand in October delivered the match ball.Melvyn Jaminet missed an early penalty due to the gusting winds, but the visitors were soon in the lead after Paul Willemse crashed over for a try which Jaminet converted.Straight from the restart, Hawick man Darcy Graham made an audacious mid-air catch and Scotland were soon on the board as Fin Russell kicked a penalty.Jaminet then took advantage of the new : kick rule and from the resultant pressure Yoram Moefana crash over for the visitors’ second try, the left wing scoring on the right. title: enduro-world-series-return-innerleithen-summer
story: ELITE athletes from across the world are set toto Peeblesshire for a mountain bike festival this summer.The Enduro World Serieswas held in Innerleithen last year following a six-year hiatus.And organisers want the event – which reportedly brought , people to the area last time out – to be “even bigger” this year.Event director Emma Wadee said: “We can’t wait to bring EWS back to Innerleithen this summer.“Our aim is to build on last year’s success to make EWS Tweed Valley one of Scotland’s best international events that celebrates the region and local community, as well as attracting visitors from around the world.”Organisers say it will be a “weekend of racing, entertainment, live music, local food, kids events, ride outs, film nights and more”.The festival is due toon June  until June  this year.Businesses and residents will receive communications about the event in the coming weeks, including letters and packs.Meanwhile there is a planned ‘town hall’ event on Thursday, April  in the Union Club.As well as attracting some of mountain biking’s top athletes, the festival could also give Peeblesshire businesses a major boost.Ahead of last year’s event, council officers said that the biking spectacle could have an “economic impact of £.m for the area”.Meanwhile, Enduro Sports Organisation – the company behind the EWS – is set to open its global headquarters in Innerleithen later this year.It follows an extensive renovation of a property on the town’s Chapel Street.From there, its growing team will coordinate the global race series, which has mountain bike events in over  countries.
